section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle: We use had + past participle to show that one action finished before another action started in the past.
section.text1: I left my keys in the car. Then I realised this.
section.text1a: I realised I'd left my keys in the car.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use the Past perfect and because to explain a past situation.
section.text3: Patrick ate a lot. He felt ill.
section.text3a: Patrick felt ill because he'd eaten a lot.

section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle: We use the Past simple to show that two actions happened at the same time.
section.text1: The telephone rang. He woke up.
section.text1a: He woke up when the telephone rang.
section.sectiontitle2: We usually use the Past simple when the order of events is clear from the context.
section.text3: A robber appeared. The robber pointed a gun at him.
section.text3a: A robber appeared and pointed a gun at him.

section.title: Past perfect
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use had not + past participle. We usually use the short form when speaking.
section.text1a: I phoned Chris but he hadn't finished my picture.
section.text2a: When we got to the station the train <b>hadn't arrived.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use had + subject + past participle.
section.text3a: Had he spoken to Jane when he e-mailed you? Yes, he had.
section.text4a: How many times had Nicola flown to Japan before 2006?
